channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Letter from India: Dangers Come With Freedom for Indian Women
item.description: Women are quickly gaining new freedoms in India, but new dangers are also arising because women are expanding their perimeter.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Demonstrators held a candle light vigil after four men convicted of raping and murdering a woman were sentenced to death in New Delhi last month.

item.title: India Ink: Morality and Mobile Phones in India
item.description: Cheap mobile phones in India present possibilities for emancipation and change for women and oppressed classes.
item.dc:creator: By ASSA DORON and ROBIN JEFFREY
item.media:description: A man speaking on a mobile phone in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on Feb. 6, 2012.

item.title: Pentagon Says Shabab Bomb Specialist Is Killed in Missile Strike in Somalia
item.description: The strike is the latest evidence that the Obama administration has escalated operations against the Shabab after the bloody siege at a shopping mall in Kenya.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: Inspectors Visit All but 2 of Syria’s Declared Chemical Sites
item.description: International inspectors say they have been unable to reach two chemical weapons sites because they are in contested areas in Syria’s civil war.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Greece’s Aggressive Pursuit of Tax Evaders Appears to Collect More Anger Than Money
item.description: New tax collection laws that were intended to cast a broader net have only fueled the public’s ire at the wealthy.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nikolis Geniatakis, at his restaurant in Archanes, Greece. Like many, he questions new tax laws. “Why aren’t they going after the big fish?” he asked.

item.title: Beijing Crash May Be Tied to Unrest in Xinjiang
item.description: A vehicle that careered along a crowded sidewalk in the capital and burst into flames killed and injured several people, and witness accounts suggested the driver had acted deliberately.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: People lay injured on a pedestrian walkway on Monday after a vehicle drove through the crowd and burst into flames at the entrance of the Forbidden City.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Says Sochi Welcomes Gays
item.description: Preparations for the Sochi Olympics have been overshadowed by international criticism of a recently enacted Russian law outlawing “propaganda of nontraditional sexual relations among minors.”
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Dispute with Azerbaijan Over Polo
item.description: Iran said that it would oppose attempts by Azerbaijan to officially register polo with the United Nations as a purely indigenous sport, arguing that polo is an international game.
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing | the Americas: Mexico: Deaths in Power Plant Attacks
item.description: Mexican security forces killed two people believed to be involved in a string of attacks on electrical installations over the weekend and captured three more, the government said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Mystery Surrounds Motive of Man With Bomb Parts in Bag
item.description: When the suspect appeared in court, it was still unclear why he had tried to bring what the police described as all but one component needed to make a bomb aboard a Los Angeles-bound flight.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: U.S. Disrupts Afghans’ Tack on Militants
item.description: Afghanistan’s attempt to gain leverage over Pakistan by cultivating an alliance with the Pakistan Taliban was discovered by the United States, which raided a convoy carrying a senior militant in the latest flash point between the nations.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry and President Hamid Karzai talked on Oct. 12 about progress on a security arrangement for after American troops leave Afghanistan.

item.title: Obama May Ban Spying on Heads of Allied States
item.description: President Obama was poised to order the ban in response to a deepening diplomatic crisis over reports that the National Security Agency had for years targeted the cellphone of Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: The United States Embassy in Berlin. Reports that the United States eavesdropped on Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, and leaders of other allied nations, have led to a diplomatic crisis.

item.title: Tadeusz Mazowiecki, Ex-Premier of Poland, Dies at 86
item.description: Mr. Mazowiecki helped form the Solidarity trade union movement and became the first non-Communist to head an Eastern bloc nation since the late 1940s.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: Tadeusz Mazowiecki, center, with Lech Walesa in Warsaw in 1989. Mr. Mazowiecki helped form the Solidarity movement, which won control of Poland’s legislature that year.

item.title: Rome Journal: Aqueducts’ Defenders Volunteer to Fill Breach in Upkeep of Park
item.description: As budget cuts and vandalism have taken a toll on a park of Rome’s ancient aqueducts, volunteers have come forth to help, but they cannot completely fill the gap.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cutbacks have taken a toll on the Park of the Aqueducts in Rome, which includes the remains of aqueducts dating to antiquity. Most of the area is privately owned.

item.title: William H. Sullivan, U.S. Ambassador to Volatile Laos and Iran, Is Dead at 90
item.description: Mr. Sullivan oversaw a secret bombing campaign in Laos and was the last United States ambassador to Iran before the 1979 hostage crisis.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY
item.media:description: William H. Sullivan was briefly held prisoner in Iran in 1979.

item.title: The Lede: Images of Flames and Smoke in Tiananmen Deleted From Chinese Social Network
item.description: After a fatal crash in Tiananmen Square, Chinese officials scrambled to clear every trace of the incident from the physical site and government censors scrubbed the social network Sina Weibo of images uploaded by witnesses.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: 5 People Killed After Vehicle Crashes at Tiananmen Square
item.description: There was no immediate indication of whether the episode, which also injured 38 people, was an accident or a deliberate attack.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: People lay injured on the pedestrian walkway east of Tiananmen Square.

item.title: Voters, in Midterm Elections, Give New Momentum to the Opposition in Argentina
item.description: A strong showing by the Renewal Front party suggested a vulnerability in the long tenure of the family of President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: Powerful Storm Lashes Northern Europe, Paralyzing Travel in Much of Britain
item.description: At least 13 people died, hundreds of thousands lost power and many people were stranded when trains, planes and ferries were canceled.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Waves battered a lighthouse during one of the most powerful storms in Europe in years.

item.title: Ex-Prison Chief Guilty Amid Cases Against Georgian Officials
item.description: The ruling came a day after presidential elections in which a big issue has been the criminal prosecutions of more than 10 former ministers.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Hundreds of Flights Canceled as Storm Batters Britain
item.description: Hurricane strength winds battered Britain, the Netherlands and Scandinavia on Monday, killing at least seven people, cutting power and forcing the cancellation of hundreds of flights and train journeys.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: Winds of up to 99 miles per hour lashed southern England and Wales in the early hours of Monday.

item.title: Prisoner Release Stirs Anger in Israeli Coalition
item.description: Right-wing members of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s coalition government tried in vain to stop future releases, part of United States-brokered peace talks.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Spain Summons American Ambassador on New Reports of N.S.A. Spying
item.description: Two Spanish newspapers reported that the National Security Agency had collected data on 60 million phone calls in the country.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: James Costos, the American ambassador, leaving the Spanish Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Madrid on Monday.

item.title: Lawyers Challenge Judges’ Authority in Trial of Chinese Activists
item.description: The trial of the three activists has drawn attention as a gauge of how far the Chinese Communist Party will go to stamp out the nationwide New Citizens Movement.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: The Lede: Rio Police Officer Is Indicted for Torture While Lecturing on ‘Smart Policing’ in New York
item.description: A Brazilian police officer who spoke at a technology conference in New York was indicted by prosecutors back home in connection with a notorious case of torture and murder by her unit.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY, SERGIO PEÇANHA and TAYLOR BARNES
item.media:description: Vanessa Coimbra, a police officer from Rio de Janeiro, spoke at a Google Ideas conference in New York on Tuesday, just hours after she was indicted by prosecutors back home.
